awd_titl_txt: Physiological Genomics of Maize Nodal Root Growth under Drought
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Robert E. Sharp (University of Missouri)

CoPIs: David M. Braun, Felix B. Fritschi, Trupti Joshi, Scott C. Peck, Jonathan T. Stemmle (University of Missouri) and Melvin J. Oliver (USDA-ARS/University of Missouri) 

Developing drought-tolerant corn varieties that make efficient use of available water is vital to sustain the estimated 9 billion global population by 2050. Corn takes up most of its water through a particular set of roots called the nodal roots. Under drought, the nodal roots must grow through dry soil to reach available water to sustain the plant. However, very little is known about the mechanisms that allow nodal roots to achieve this essential feat. This project will use a combination of physiological and genomics approaches to define the molecular mechanisms underlying how the nodal roots are able to maintain growth under drought. The information generated by the project will lead to the development of innovative approaches to enable corn and other cereal crops to access more water and increase yield under drought, and will thereby contribute to the essential goals of increased food security and stability. In addition to the training of students and postdoctoral associates, the project will provide summer research training internships for undergraduate students from Fort Valley State University, a Historically Black University (HBCU) located in Fort Valley (GA). The project will also disseminate research findings and provide information to the general public through various communication, technical training and outreach activities. These include but are not limited to science communication workshops involving journalism students and hands-on training workshops on metabolomics and the use of bioinformatics tools to analyze and integrate multi-omics datasets.  

This project integrates root physiology and functional genomics [transcriptomics, plasma membrane proteomics, and metabolomics (including hormones)] to deliver a comprehensive understanding of nodal root growth responses to water deficit stress in both controlled laboratory studies and in the field. The project focuses on a maize inbred line that has been shown to exhibit superior ability for nodal root growth under water-limited conditions. A collaborative interdisciplinary team will address the following specific objectives: 1) elucidation of the physiological and molecular basis of nodal root growth responses to water stress using a novel divided-chamber model system for precise imposition of water deficit conditions around the growing roots; 2) characterization of nodal root growth and root growth zone transcriptomic responses in response to water stress in the field, using "drought simulators" for precise imposition of the timing, intensity and duration of drought; and 3) integration and analysis of all datasets using a suite of informatics tools to identify candidate genes that will be genetically validated in plants. This multidisciplinary strategy provides unique opportunities to greatly improve basic understanding of root biology under drought, and to broadly train the next generation of plant scientists. Data and biological materials generated by this project will be accessible to a project website (to be developed) and through deposition to long-term repositories such as the Maize Genetics Cooperative (for germplasm), and MaizeGDB, Gramene and the NCBI's GEO and SRA (for sequence and phenotypic datasets).

por.por_cntn:
Robert E Sharp, David M Braun, Felix B Fritschi, Trupti Joshi, Melvin J Oliver, Scott C Peck, Jonathan T Stemmle

University of Missouri, Columbia

Developing drought-tolerant corn varieties that make efficient use of available soil water is vital to sustain the estimated 9 billion global population by 2050. Mature corn plants take up most of their water through a particular set of roots called the nodal roots. These roots grow from the base of the stem, and under drought conditions, must grow through dry surface soil layers to reach available water at greater depth to sustain the plant. However, very little is known about the physiological and genetic mechanisms that allow nodal roots to achieve this essential feat. This project used a multidisciplinary approach encompassing studies in both the laboratory (controlled environment growth chambers) and field to investigate the biological mechanisms that determine how nodal roots are able to maintain growth under water deficit stress.

This project integrated root physiology, functional genomics (relationships between genes and their coordination to generate a biological function) and bioinformatics (using software to examine the large amount of data from the research) to deliver a comprehensive understanding of nodal root growth responses to limited water supply. The project focused on comparisons of maize inbred lines with contrasting abilities for nodal root growth maintenance under soil drying conditions. The experiments utilized specialized techniques that allowed researchers to reproduce different water deficit conditions in controlled environments. In the laboratory studies, a divided root chamber system was developed to study nodal root growth responses to precise variations in soil water status independently of the seedling root system. In the field, mobile "rainout shelters" were used to control the timing, intensity and duration of drought despite variations in precipitation during and between growing seasons. 

The results included the discovery that in the tolerant genotype, the region of growing tissue at the tip of the nodal roots has the ability to maintain its water status even when the roots are growing through very dry soil. This finding indicates that the roots have the ability to "waterproof" themselves and prevent cellular dehydration when exposed to the surrounding dry soil environment. A system to examine the observable characteristics of the nodal roots, called phenotyping, was developed to screen across multiple genotypes for diversity in nodal root growth in drying soil as well as in biomass partitioning (how the plant controls where metabolites are sent to support growth) between the nodal and seedling root systems under drought conditions. Large genetic variation was identified in both traits, and future studies will address which of these root system characteristics results in greater water uptake from depth and thus sustained crop development under prolonged drought conditions.

The genetic and biochemical information generated by the project will lead to the development of innovative approaches to enable corn and other cereal crops to access more water and increase yield under drought, and will thereby contribute to the essential goals of increased global food security and stability. In addition to the training of numerous graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral associates, the project provided summer research internships for four undergraduate students from Fort Valley State University, a Historically Black University (HBCU) located in Fort Valley, Georgia.

The project integrated scientific investigation with science communication by merging the training of plant biology and journalism students, thereby producing an interdisciplinary team with enhanced abilities to disseminate the project's research findings to the general public, farmers and legislators, as well as to other scientists. Various outreach activities included presentations of a booth on "Getting to the Root of Drought" at the Missouri State Fair, and an invited presentation by two of the project's graduate students at the Global Plant Council international workshop on "Embedding Policy and Communication Programs in Research Collaborations" in Baltimore, Maryland, in 2018. The team also posted a series of stories for the general public on the project's website https://rootsindrought.missouri.edu/ and YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC70VwyFCVlpMnwIZ1izxjFw.
